Posts.Content: Forgive me if there are threads covering all this but I am 44 and a bit freaked out. I just had my first PSA test back and the PSA was 3.5 and the percent free was 9%. Dr said this is very concerning but doesn't want to do biopsy yet, rather repeat test in 4 months. 4 months seems like forever right now. Question - what would you do? (second opinion, etc?) Would you tell your wife? I am already miserably ill from a variety of maladies - Chron's disease, ulcerative colitis, irritable bowel syndrome, Hiatal Hernia, Barretts Esophagus, Severe Sleep apnea, been a smoker most of my life. Thanks for any and all.

Posts.Title: PSA results question

Posts.Content: I have had a steady rise in PSA over the years from 3 to 6.6 Additionally I have experienced gradually worsening ED to the point of impotence. I learned about 15 months ago I had extremely low T, I wanted to go on TRT but my Uro did a biopsy first which was negative. The TRT helped for like a month. Then limpy returned. Increased amount of T, helped a bit. Nocturnal issues returned, went on Cialis which helped a bit with both nocturnal and ED. Several weeks ago I went through a dreadful couple of weeks where I was suffering from tenesmus combine with persistent urge to pee as well. I assumed it was a UC flare (I have Ulcerative Colitis), I started smoking cigarettes again and the symptoms went away in two days. Less than a week after the symptoms subsided I had a blood draw. PSA was 14.4!!! I am scared $hitless and my follow up with my Dr isnt for another two weeks (he's away for vacation). Could I have prostatitis?
Posts.Title: PSA shot up

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman You dont say when your last PSA, the 6.6 result was. If it was in the last year or 18m9nths, its possible, even probable that its prostatitis. Or BPH or both. PSA is not a test for cancer, its a test that tells you if there is something going on with the prostate. Typically, from my experience at least, but also from what Ive read here and elsewhere, PC will cause a slow but steady rising trend in PSA over time, a spike like this is often in fact, Prostatitis. Thank you for your response. The 6.6 was in May
Posts.Title: PSA shot up
